boardgame.name: Fantastic Races of the Otherverese: The Urlock
Fantastic Races of the Otherverse: The Urlock
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Fantastic Races of the Otherverse series converts the most interesting, unusual and powerful player races from Otherverse Games' D20 Modern-powered settings: Otherverse America, Psi-Watch, Galaxy Command and Black Tokyo, and adapts them for use with the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game. More than a just simple conversion to the new rule set, these short sourcebooks imagine how heroes from super-scientific worlds would look in campaigns where magic and the divine are the norm. This series of supplements also provides a few new hints at how the vast and interconnected multiverse of Otherverse Games fits together.

In Galaxy Command, the powerfully built Urloks are an alien race of psychically enhanced warriors. They are known for their courage and sense of honor. The bear like humanoids have recently entered the galactic stage, after a successful first contact by Galaxy Command's heroic astronauts.

For the Pathfinder Role Playing Game the Urlocks have been re-imagined...

According to the Urlok's own creation stories, the bear-like giants fell from heaven long ago. Otherworldly and somber, Urloks know the Prime Material Plane as a cosmic penance for racial sins long forgotten. Talk to any Urlok and if you can over come the race's legendary taciturnity, he will tell you that once upon a time, his race were the soldiers of Heaven itself. During a great battle against a legendary cosmic evil, Urlok soldiers fled the battlefield, and for their cowardice the entire race was cast down. Urloks strive to atone for their mythical ancestors' betrayal.

Courage and loyalty are foremost virtues for the race, and an Urlok knight would rather die than betray a trust. Oathbreakers and cowards are punished harshly, with the normally noble bear-men reaching extremes of torture and atrocity that give even savage humanoids like Orcs and Hobgoblins pause when punishing traitors within their proud race. Urloks who show fear or even the slightest trace of deception brand and scar themselves with their mightly claws. More severe offenses are punished with the amputation of fingers, hands or even whole arms. Urloks hold themselves to incredibly harsh standards and a completely unscarred Urlok is a one in a million rarity. Among their own kind, the rare unscarred Urloks are treated with a living saint's respect, and a bit of jealous suspicion: are they truly as righteous as they claim, or are they simply too afraid of pain to scar themselves for hidden offenses?

Urloks live far from most other humanoids. They prefer the cold places at the top and bottom of the world. Because of their distance from civilization and their savage and masochistic punishments, the Urloks rarely receive a warm reception in peaceful humanoid kingdoms. Urloks venturing into warmer regions are often mercenaries. Dozens of kingdoms, both good and evil, hire the bear-folk as indomitable shock troops. Urlok tenacity and courage is well known among fighting men, and the race's soldiers will display reserves of bravado and willpower unknown in other races.

As of 2107, the Ubasti work with the Choicer nation as free sentient beings, and are beloved by Choicer America for their loyalty and courage.

For the Pathfinder setting the Ubasti have been re-imagined as nomadic, long-lived sentient lion-folk. Ubasti prides have prowled the veldt since before the bipedal races began recording history. boardgame.name: Necropunk: Welshen
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Sentinels to the front, Necromancers to the back and today's shaping up to be a good day to be a welshen!

Grab your war knife, dodge some bullets, and get to killing because this book's for all the Welshen players out there!

We've got 40+ pages of welshen goodness crammed into this book (quite efficiently I might add).

We've got archetypes, prestige classes, weapons, feats, and all the lore for you next Necropunk game!

Included:

5 Archetypes
h’Devvel: An artistic society role that keeps the Empire from losing perspective. It's a wild card archetype that plays a bit like a bard, a bit like a diplomat, and a lot like a welshen!
Masque: A magdaline welshen diplomat archetype that focuses on extreme emotional control and hyper-rationality. It's a small archetype but it gives you new options for your moral support class feature and can make things more thematically appropriate for a magdaline.
h’Teach: A master scavenger from the magdavuul. This book includes a new use for Appraise and they are masters at it. This diplomat archetype includes a lot of tech related things so you can blend the engineer in with it.
Rek'el: The flip side of the h'teach is the rek'el. They are a magdavuul engineer archetype who can scrap things and rebuild better things from the salvage. They also get less progresses but get the ability to switch them out.
h’Vuul: We did a ranger archetype for the magdavuul's spec. ops commandos. They gain the ability to go higher in phase order and have some other very unique mechanics I don't want to spoil! (Plus a new weapon style for welshen rangers)

2 Prestige Classes
Hn’ist Nomad: Though bizarre chanting and adherence to an almost Zen philosophy the Hn’ist gains a unique ability to suppress things like phase order abilities, psionic powers, and magpie abilities.
h'Te'shen (Master Qu’em): This provides a high level prestige class option for the qu'em. It gives them more of a support role while not necessarily sacrificing their role as damage dealers.

Lesser Clans
Clan X’el: Ex-prime bloodline members who have joined the welshen.
Clan Mac’Bel: Historians looking to head back to earth who have invented a predictive method that is said to be 92% accurate.
Clan Fe’Shex: Murderous war mongers who taught the welshen to fight originally. Their punishingly brutal fau quan style of martial arts is believed to have influenced qu'em's development.
Clan Dem’Rel: A diseased clan who are carriers of the deadly "dem'rel fever". Used as biological weapons of war, they live their lives in isolation, and protective hazmat suits.
Clan Sil'van: A peaceful clan of Buddhist pacifists who swear not to draw blood even while they wear a welshen war knife in their sash...

Qu'em Schools (Archetypes)
School of the Sil'van: Unable to cause harm, these qu'em practice a modified form of the art that leads to less-lethal conflict resolution.
School of the Golden Lion: A brutal style of armored qu'em that the fe'shex and magdaline are known to use.
School of the Crying Birds (Le’Sara Qu’em): A two weapon style of qu'em that blends elements from the artistic h’Devvel that developed it.

Sections on Welshen Culture: We include sections on topics like death, welshen women, economics, homefleets, honor duels, and give further explanation for welshen weapon taboos. We also touch on renegade qu'em and explore the mysteries of the origin of the welshen on Earth...
How to Build Clan Member: We have a guide on how to build members of each clan (from the t'ka main clan to the lesser clans).
20+ New Feats: Including combat, social, and style feats. Also, 3 campaign traits.
New Welshen Weapons: 5 new weapons (including a guns?!) and 6 new pieces of necrotech (some war tokens too).
New Use for Appraise: Allowing you to identify weapon mods and other aspects of gear!
Qu’em Sojourns: Similar to story feats, qu'em can undertake these role-playing intense journeys of discovery to explore aspects of the qu'em lifestyle. They have an extremely strict initial requirement that looses up if you survive and provides you with a bonus!

boardgame.name: Raven: Gang Wars
boardgame.description:
A 2-5 Player game that pits mobs against each other, fighting for territory while building and fortifying their own empire. This is a light resource management game with dice battling, card management, and medium to heavy card strategy.

Your goal is to take over all opposing territories or remove the other players from the game by killing them or crippling their resources/ability to the point of defeat. As one of the Gang Boss's in the game, during your turn you can assign your men into certain locations to extort money (to be used to buy or upgrade items/weapons); train your men with upgradable abilities to spy, fight, influence, or lead better; visit the black market auction with other players for high caliber items, or lead full scale attacks against others to try to overrun their businesses and territories.

The game includes 5 different decks (54 cards per deck) that represent different mobs, such as the Italian Mafia, Chinese Triads, Japanese Yakuza, Urban Dynasty, and Latino Cartels. In addition, other decks currently available separately are the 5-0 and the Russian Bratva.

Types of cards include Boss Cards, Recruitment Cards, Action Cards, Gear Cards, Black Market Cards, and Event Cards.

boardgame.name: Wii Fit U Meter
boardgame.description:
Stay on track at home or away with the Fit Meter

Your Wii Fit U lifestyle doesn’t stop at the front door. Now you can track all your activity—wherever you are. Just clip on the Fit Meter on your way out and sync it with a touch of a button when you get home.

The Fit Meter does a lot more than count your steps. It also has an acceleration sensor (to measure intensity) and an atmospheric pressure sensor (to measure altitude changes).

This means the Fit Meter can more accurately calculate how many calories you burn, based on what you’re doing. Running up stairs, for example, will torch more calories than taking the elevator—even though the distance is the same.

See how much you’ve accomplished by syncing the Fit Meter to your Wii Fit U profile at the touch of a button. You’ll get detailed graphs of all your activity, including how many calories you've burned and how many steps you've walked.

Source: The Publisher Website.
